comments.content:
Well... I was partially wrong and partially right: 
 
"The <get> and <get-config> operations are used to retrieve data from the server. The <get> operation retrieves all configuration and state data, and the <get-config> operation retrieves the configuration data from only a specific datastore"

So for this particular question: 
A. and C doesn't exist
B. "get" method doesn't accept any other parameter than "filter" and "filter_type"

So D. is STILL the right answer

discussion.content:
D. get_config is still the correct answer.

But I want to clarify, you can either use "get", or "get_config" to retrieve the config of the device. But the key thing is that the "get" method doesn't accept any other parameter than "filter" and "filter_type" and by default points to the "running" datastore. 
If you need to target a different datastore than "running" you need to use get_config. Maybe using "get" and a specific filter can target a different datastore, but it seems unlikely and impractical.

Selected Answer: D
In the netconfig method,
<get> </get> - operational data
<get-config></get-config> - config 
<edit-config></edit-config> - edit config

In the netconfig method,
<get> </get> - operational data
<get-config></get-config> - config 
<edit-config></edit-config> - edit config

questions.question_text: What does the command boot ipxe forever switch 1 perform when executed on a Cisco IOS XE device?

choices.A: It continuously sends DHCP requests for iPXE until the device boots with an image.
choices.B: It continuously sends DNS requests for iPXE until the device restarts.
choices.D: It continuously sends DHCP requests for iPXE until the device restarts.
choices.C: It continuously sends DNS requests for iPXE until the device boots with an image.

discussion.content: answer is C
entered all code in pycharm, C is the only one that works, the exhibit is a dict and that's the only way to get out the values in a print statement

B looks like some sort of quasi class utilisation and here we have a dictionary, the proper way to work with a dictionary is shown in C
